DA66ED70803F43618545FB0B5F77BBE2.description:
Identify the natural resources used in the process of
making various manufactured products.

5AAB1DA738624BFBA129134871DA746F.description:
Identify and categorize the basic needs of living
organisms as they relate to the environment.

891D0839E49846F2AD06E41DB42EBE72.description: Identify and use water conservation practices.

13CC8A12A07B4EDFBE27BDE5AB72A0A2.description: Observe and discuss evaporation and condensation.

17DB984499524827986C4F08B01EAF36.description:
Biogeochemical Cycles : The biogeochemical cycles in the Earth systems include the flow of
microscopic and macroscopic resources from one reservoir in the hydrosphere, geosphere,
atmosphere, or biosphere to another, are driven by Earth's internal and external sources of energy,
and are impacted by human activity.

A5D21E628F83457BBADC445C4058525F.description:
Observe and document daily weather conditions and
discuss how the weather influences your activities for the
day.

4974FF99340C4E23AD826245170AE4A5.description:
Climate and Weather : Earth’s weather and climate systems are the result of complex
interactions between land, ocean, ice, and atmosphere.

D94F7FB91FE0469D81893CBB968E2B07.description:
Describe the relationship between the Sun and plant
growth.

DD926A7DDFDA42E88F88BC61DED3B2A6.description: Energy in Earth Systems : Internal and external sources of energy drive Earth systems.

ADACD035F88D471BA01C30CF36D9482E.description:
Describe Earth materials using appropriate terms, such as
hard, soft, dry, wet, heavy, and light.

06BC8365E2F24B98822887D99560DA8B.description:
Properties of Earth Materials : Earth’s composition is unique, is related to the origin of our
solar system, and provides us with the raw resources needed to sustain life.

BB67197DE43549DA8895C8E3AEBEFDCB.description:
Determine a set of general rules describing when the Sun
and Moon are visible based on actual sky observations.

4E4E5466A70E4626AB1E1B5067CC49D8.description:
Objects in the Universe : Our universe has been expanding and evolving for 13.7 billion years
under the influence of gravitational and nuclear forces. As gravity governs its expansion,
organizational patterns, and the movement of celestial bodies, nuclear forces within stars govern its
evolution through the processes of stellar birth and death. These same processes governed the
formation of our solar system 4.6 billion years ago.

4CDA26E4798C436E85284EF60BD80548.description:
Earth Systems Science: All students will understand that Earth operates as a set of complex,
dynamic, and interconnected systems, and is a part of the all-encompassing system of the universe.

18E92FF45E6D4D058B3F8401354948C0.description:
Describe how similar structures found in different
organisms (e.g., eyes, ears, mouths) have similar
functions and enable those organisms to survive in
different environments

610AC93C9B024026AE4759D0962DE2E6.description:
Describe similarities and differences in observable traits
between parents and offspring.

C4219D56906A41629CC882E3980FEC68.description:
Evolution and Diversity: Sometimes, differences between organisms of the same kind
provide advantages for surviving and reproducing in different environments. These selective
differences may lead to dramatic changes in characteristics of organisms in a population over
extremely long periods of time.

F86EAB0377094B5FA810BCD9FF3FED10.description:
Determine the characteristic changes that occur during
the life cycle of plants and animals by examining a variety
of species, and distinguish between growth and
development.

859D1546FEBD4F178926FA7EDE14DEF1.description:
Record the observable characteristics of plants and
animals to determine the similarities and differences
between parents and their offspring.

93FB11D139F1438B8A8E8ECB6D846E71.description:
D. Heredity and Reproduction : Organisms reproduce, develop, and have predictable life cycles.
Organisms contain genetic information that influences their traits, and they pass this on to their
offspring during reproduction.

A7C209D26E084AC1ACC2B41C8DB781C2.description:
Communicate ways that humans protect habitats and/or
improve conditions for the growth of the plants and
animals that live there, or ways that humans might harm
habitats.

CAA210636CC546FDA015D4777E19B4BA.description:
Identify the characteristics of a habitat that enable the
habitat to support the growth of many different plants and
animals.

7E9D3BC57CE14A04B3944FB39D2C3AA7.description:
Describe the ways in which organisms interact with each
other and their habitats in order to meet basic needs.

127CA064AE1C46379BE9636B80F6EF45.description:
Interdependence : All animals and most plants depend on both other organisms and their
environment to meet their basic needs.

E8C7B65BAF0B4B328CAB95070323FB0D.description:
Explain that most plants get water from soil through their
roots and gather light through their leaves.

A598CD343F8A42EBB27982653E72A26A.description: Compare how different animals obtain food and water.

1F2749CF5BA64F4BA4815931DBAF0C9F.description:
Describe the requirements for the care of plants and
animals related to meeting their energy needs.

44A89EC4ACA24FB8B7D729D292AB71B6.description:
Matter and Energy Transformations : Food is required for energy and building cellular
materials. Organisms in an ecosystem have different ways of obtaining food, and some organisms
obtain their food directly from other organisms.

9FD5E0298E784B79BFCADF4458DC2CB3.description:
Group living and nonliving things according to the
characteristics that they share.

C118B14A75EA47BCB3070E9CED76F315.description:
Organization and Development : Living organisms are composed of cellular units (structures)
that carry out functions required for life. Cellular units are composed of molecules, which also carry
out biological functions.

650C4FC159124DE0BF9DC4087013DC99.description:
Life Science: All students will understand that life science principles are powerful conceptual
tools for making sense of the complexity, diversity, and interconnectedness of life on Earth. Order in
natural systems arises in accordance with rules that govern the physical world, and the order of
natural systems can be modeled and predicted through the use of mathematics.

53E859D47A6043D998B5755044FD26CC.description:
Distinguish a force that acts by direct contact with an
object (e.g., by pushing or pulling) from a force that can
act without direct contact (e.g., the attraction between a
magnet and a steel paper clip).

D5DE17A377BE4689828C121DC32C9F8F.description:
Predict an object’s relative speed, path, or how far it will
travel using various forces and surfaces.

E46A2045B57443A089EA4EA6068489F5.description:
Investigate and model the various ways that inanimate
objects can move.

7CA3643AEA1B4A77B36F5C29AA5B6B0E.description:
Forces and Motion : It takes energy to change the motion of objects. The energy change is
understood in terms of forces.

B8533CD4ED144C9BAF14EB5A55DDDB7D.description:
Predict and confirm the brightness of a light, the volume
of sound, or the amount of heat when given the number
of batteries, or the size of batteries.

697E1090E65B4B87A558DC02845FE487.description:
Energy Transfer and Conservation : The conservation of energy can be demonstrated by
keeping track of familiar forms of energy as they are transferred from one object to another.

5A30EE891ECF497894EE5002898F9BFF.description:
Present evidence that represents the relationship between
a light source, solid object, and the resulting shadow.

46C219853B1D470B8A9AE034572D63FB.description:
Apply a variety of strategies to collect evidence that
validates the principle that if there is no light, objects
cannot be seen.

9071E5A74AF94DD1A91F4662B17ECC97.description:
Compare, citing evidence, the heating of different colored
objects placed in full sunlight.

F73F4C46917C483B8ECB27DA82A33877.description:
Forms of Energy : Knowing the characteristics of familiar forms of energy, including potential
and kinetic energy, is useful in coming to the understanding that, for the most part, the natural
world can be explained and is predictable.

523B27C93A994825809A4723AF9AE79C.description:
Generate accurate data and organize arguments to show
that not all substances respond the same way when
heated or cooled, using common materials, such as
shortening or candle wax.

2D4E8DFB997A49AF9A8452919262A10D.description:
Changes in Matter : Substances can undergo physical or chemical changes to form new
substances. Each change involves energy.

2926622126DD41259C2A9D353C82A401.description: Identify common objects as solids, liquids, or gases.

DD81E2B61F114CA6B9BEB83CC96DD994.description:
Sort and describe objects based on the materials of which
they are made and their physical properties.

2707889BA05C4E1BA9018E6C91F27E80.description:
Properties of Matter : All objects and substances in the natural world are composed of matter.
Matter has two fundamental properties: matter takes up space, and matter has inertia.

DF4BA6DADAAA447FB6DEDF1E86E4E760.description:
Physical Science: All students will understand that physical science principles, including
fundamental ideas about matter, energy, and motion, are powerful conceptual tools for making
sense of phenomena in physical, living, and Earth systems science.
